text: PART III:  ON THE ORIGIN AND NATURE OF THE EMOTIONS
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Most writers on the emotions and on human conduct seem
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to be treating rather of matters outside nature than of natural
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: phenomena following nature's general laws.  They appear to
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conceive man to be situated in nature as a kingdom within a
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: kingdom:  for they believe that he disturbs rather than follows
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nature's order, that he has absolute control over his actions,
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and that he is determined solely by himself.  They attribute
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: human infirmities and fickleness, not to the power of nature
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in general, but to some mysterious flaw in the nature of man,
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which accordingly they bemoan, deride, despise, or, as
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: usually happens, abuse:  he, who succeeds in hitting off
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the weakness of the human mind more eloquently or more
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: acutely than his fellows, is looked upon as a seer.  Still there
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: has been no lack of very excellent men (to whose toil and
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: industry I confess myself much indebted), who have written
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: many noteworthy things concerning the right way of life,
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and have given much sage advice to mankind.  But no one,
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: so far as I know, has defined the nature and strength of the
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: emotions, and the power of the mind against them for their
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: restraint.
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: I do not forget, that the illustrious Descartes, though he
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: believed, that the mind has absolute power over its actions,
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: strove to explain human emotions by their primary causes,
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and, at the same time, to point out a way, by which the mind
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: might attain to absolute dominion over them.  However,
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in my opinion, he accomplishes nothing beyond a display
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of the acuteness of his own great intellect, as I will show
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in the proper place.  For the present I wish to revert to
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: those, who would rather abuse or deride human emotions
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: than understand them.  Such persons will, doubtless think
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: it strange that I should attempt to treat of human vice and
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: folly geometrically, and should wish to set forth with rigid
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: reasoning those matters which they cry out against as
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: repugnant to reason, frivolous, absurd, and dreadful.
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: However, such is my plan.  Nothing comes to pass in nature,
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which can be set down to a flaw therein; for nature is always
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the same, and everywhere one and the same in her efficacy
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and power of action; that is, nature's laws and ordinances,
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: whereby all things come to pass and change from one form
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to another, are everywhere and always the same; so that
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: there should be one and the same method of understanding
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the nature of all things whatsoever, namely, through nature's
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: universal laws and rules.  Thus the passions of hatred, anger,
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: envy, and so on, considered in themselves, follow from this
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: same necessity and efficacy of nature; they answer to certain
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: definite causes, through which they are understood, and
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: possess certain properties as worthy of being known as
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the properties of anything else, whereof the contemplation
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in itself affords us delight.  I shall, therefore, treat of the
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nature and strength of the emotions according to the same
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: method, as I employed heretofore in my investigations
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: concerning God and the mind.  I shall consider human
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: actions and desires in exactly the same manner, as though
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: I were concerned with lines, planes, and solids.
title: Ethics — Part 3

text: DEFINITIONS
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: I. By an 'adequate' cause, I mean a cause through which
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: its effect can be clearly and distinctly perceived.  By an
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: 'inadequate' or partial cause, I mean a cause through which,
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: by itself, its effect cannot be understood.
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: II. I say that we 'act' when anything takes place, either
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: within us or externally to us, whereof we are the adequate
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: cause; that is (by the foregoing definition) when through
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: our nature something takes place within us or externally
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to us, which can through our nature alone be clearly and
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: distinctly understood.  On the other hand, I say that we
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: are passive as regards something when that something
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: takes place within us, or follows from our nature externally,
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: we being only the partial cause.
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: III. By 'emotion' I mean the modifications of the body,
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: whereby the active power of the said body is increased
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: or diminished, aided or constrained, and also the ideas
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of such modifications.
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: N.B. If we can be the adequate cause of any of these
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: modifications, I then call the emotion an activity,
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: otherwise I call it a passion, or state wherein the mind
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is passive.
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: POSTULATES
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: I. The human body can be affected in many ways, whereby
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: its power of activity is increased or diminished, and also
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in other ways which do not render its power of activity
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: either greater or less.
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: N.B. This postulate or axiom rests on Postulate i. and
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Lemmas v. and vii., which see after II. xiii.
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: II. The human body can undergo many changes, and,
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nevertheless, retain the impressions or traces of objects
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (cf. II. Post. v.), and, consequently, the same images
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of things (see note II. xvii.).
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: PROPOSITIONS
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: I. Our mind is in certain cases active, and in certain cases
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: passive.  In so far as it has adequate ideas it is necessarily
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: active, and in so far as it has inadequate ideas, it is
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: necessarily passive.
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: >>>>>Proof--In every human mind there are some
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: adequate ideas, and some ideas that are fragmentary
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and confused (II. xl. note).  Those ideas which are
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: adequate in the mind are adequate also in God, inasmuch
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: as he constitutes the essence of the mind (II. xl. Cor.),
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and those which are inadequate in the mind are likewise
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (by the same Cor.) adequate in God, not inasmuch as he
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: contains in himself the essence of the given mind alone,
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: but as he, at the same time, contains the minds of other
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: things.  Again, from any given idea some effect must
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: necessarily follow (I. xxxvi.); of this effect God is the
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: adequate cause (III. Def. i.), not inasmuch as he is
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: infinite, but inasmuch as he is conceived as affected by
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the given idea (II. ix.).  But of that effect whereof God
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is the cause, inasmuch as he is affected by an idea which
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is adequate in a given mind, of that effect, I repeat, the
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mind in question is the adequate cause (II. xi. Cor.).
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Therefore our mind, in so far as it has adequate ideas
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (III. Def. ii.), is in certain cases necessarily active;
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: this was our first point.  Again, whatsoever necessarily
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: follows from the idea which is adequate in God, not by
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: virtue of his possessing in himself the mind of one man
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: only, but by virtue of his containing, together with the
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mind of that one man, the minds of other things also,
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of such an effect (II. xi. Cor.) the mind of the given man
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is not an adequate, but only a partial cause; thus
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (III. Def. ii.) the mind, inasmuch as it has inadequate
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: ideas, is in certain cases necessarily passive; this was
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: our second point.  Therefore our mind, &c.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: <<<<<Corollary--Hence it follows that the mind is more
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: or less liable to be acted upon, in proportion as it possesses
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: inadequate ideas, and, contrariwise, is more or less active
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in proportion as it possesses adequate ideas.
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: II. Body cannot determine mind to think, neither can mind
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: determine body to motion or rest or any state different
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: from these, if such there be.
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: >>>>>Proof--All modes of thinking have for their cause
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: God, by virtue of his being a thinking thing, and not by
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: virtue of his being displayed under any other attribute (II.
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: vi.).  That, therefore, which determines the mind to thought
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is a mode of thought, and not a mode of extension; that
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is (II. Def. i.), it is not body.  This was our first point.
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Again, the motion and rest of a body must arise from
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: another body, which has also been determined to a state
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of motion or rest by a third body, and absolutely
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: everything which takes place in a body must spring from
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: God, in so far as he is regarded as affected by some
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mode of extension, and not by some mode of thought
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (II. vi.); that is, it cannot spring from the mind, which
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is a mode of thought.  This was our second point.
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Therefore body cannot determine mind, &c.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: *****Note--This is made more clear by what was said
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in the note to II. vii., namely, that mind and body are one
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and the same thing, conceived first under the attribute of
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: thought, secondly, under the attribute of extension.  Thus
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: it follows that the order or concatenation of things is identical,
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: whether nature be conceived under the one attribute or the
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: other; consequently the order of states of activity and
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: passivity in our body is simultaneous in nature with the
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: order of states of activity and passivity in the mind.
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: The same conclusion is evident from the manner in which
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: we proved II. xii.
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Nevertheless, though such is the case, and though there
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: be no further room for doubt, I can scarcely believe,
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: until the fact is proved by experience, that men can be
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: induced to consider the question calmly and fairly, so firmly
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: are they convinced that it is merely at the bidding of the
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mind, that the body is set in motion or at rest, or performs
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: a variety of actions depending solely on the mind's will
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: or the exercise of thought.  However, no one has hitherto
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: laid down the limits to the powers of the body, that is, no
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: one has as yet been taught by experience what the body
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: can accomplish solely by the laws of nature, in so far as
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: she is regarded as extension.  No one hitherto has gained
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: such an accurate knowledge of the bodily mechanism, that
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: he can explain all its functions; nor need I call attention
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to the fact that many actions are observed in the lower
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: animals, which far transcend human sagacity, and
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that somnambulists do many things in their sleep, which
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: they would not venture to do when awake:  these instances
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: are enough to show, that the body can by the sole laws
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of its nature do many things which the mind wonders at.
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Again, no one knows how or by what means the mind
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: moves the body, nor how many various degrees of motion
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: it can impart to the body, nor how quickly it can move it.
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Thus, when men say that this or that physical action has
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: its origin in the mind, which latter has dominion over the
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: body, they are using words without meaning, or are
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: confessing in specious phraseology that they are ignorant
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of the cause of the said action, and do not wonder at it.
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: But, they will say, whether we know or do not know the
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: means whereby the mind acts on the body, we have, at
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: any rate, experience of the fact that unless the human mind
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is in a fit state to think, the body remains inert.  Moreover,
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: we have experience, that the mind alone can determine
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: whether we speak or are silent, and a variety of similar
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: states which, accordingly, we say depend on the mind's
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: decree.  But, as to the first point, I ask such objectors,
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: whether experience does not also teach, that if the body
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: be inactive the mind is simultaneously unfitted for
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: thinking?  For when the body is at rest in sleep, the mind
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: simultaneously is in a state of torpor also, and has no
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: power of thinking, such as it possesses when the body
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is awake.  Again, I think everyone's experience will
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: confirm the statement, that the mind is not at all times
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: equally fit for thinking on a given subject, but according
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: as the body is more or less fitted for being stimulated by
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the image of this or that object, so also is the mind more
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: or less fitted for contemplating the said object.
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the laws of nature considered as extended substance,
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: we should be able to deduce the causes of buildings,
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: pictures, and things of that kind, which are produced
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: only by human art; nor would the human body, unless
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: it were determined and led by the mind, be capable of
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: out that the objectors cannot fix the limits of the body's
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: power, or say what can be concluded from a consideration
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of its sole nature, whereas they have experience of many
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: things being accomplished solely by the laws of nature,
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which they would never have believed possible except
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to the mechanism of the human body, which far surpasses
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in complexity all that has been put together by human art,
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: not to repeat what I have already shown, namely, that
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: from nature, under whatever attribute she be considered,
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

title: Ethics — Part 3

title: Ethics — Part 3

title: Ethics — Part 3

title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and dislikes should meet with universal approval, is really ambition

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: desires (appetere), that the rest of mankind should live according
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

title: Ethics — Part 3

text: XXXII. If we conceive that anyone takes delight in something,
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which only one person can possess, we shall endeavour to bring
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: it about that the man in question shall not gain possession thereof.
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: >>>>>Proof--From the mere fact of our conceiving that another
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: person takes delight in a thing (III. xxvii. and Cor.) we shall
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: ourselves love that thing and desire to take delight therein.  But
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: we assumed that the pleasure in question would be prevented by
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: another's delight in its object; we shall, therefore, endeavour to
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: prevent his possession thereof (III. xxviii.).  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: *****Note--We thus see that man's nature is generally so
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: constituted, that he takes pity on those who fare ill, and envies
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: those who fare well with an amount of hatred proportioned to
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: his own love for the goods in their possession.  Further, we see
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that from the same property of human nature, whence it follows
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that men are merciful, it follows also that they are envious and
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: ambitious.  Lastly, if we make appeal to Experience, we shall
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: find that she entirely confirms what we have said; more especially
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: if we turn our attention to the first years of our life.  We find that
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: children, whose body is continually, as it were, in equilibrium,
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: laugh or cry simply because they see others laughing or crying;
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: moreover, they desire forthwith to imitate whatever they see
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: others doing, and to possess themselves of whatever they
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conceive as delighting others:  inasmuch as the images of things
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: are, as we have said, modifications of the human body, or
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: modes wherein the human body is affected and disposed by
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: external causes to act in this or that manner.
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: XXXIII. When we love a thing similar to ourselves we endeavour,
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: as far as we can, to bring about that it should love us in return.
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: >>>>>Proof--That which we love we endeavour, as far as we
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: can, to conceive in preference to anything else (III. xii.).  If the
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: thing be similar to ourselves, we shall endeavour to affect it
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: pleasurably in preference to anything else (III. xxix.).  In other
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: words, we shall endeavour, as far as we can, to bring it about,
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that the thing should be affected with pleasure accompanied by
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the idea of ourselves, that is (III. xiii. note), that it should love
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: us in return.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: XXXIV. The greater the emotion with which we conceive a
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: loved object to be affected towards us, the greater will be our
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: complacency.
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: >>>>>Proof--We endeavour (III. xxxiii.), as far as we can, to
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: bring about, that what we love should love us in return:  in other
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: words, that what we love should be affected with pleasure
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: accompanied by the idea of ourself as cause.  Therefore, in
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: proportion as the loved object is more pleasurably affected
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: because of us, our endeavour will be assisted. --that is (III. xi.
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and note) the greater will be our pleasure.  But when we take
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: pleasure in the fact, that we pleasurably affect something similar
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to ourselves, we regard ourselves with pleasure (III. xxx);
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: therefore the greater the emotion with which we conceive a
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: loved object to be affected, &c.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: XXXV. If anyone conceives, that an object of his love joins
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: itself to another with closer bonds of friendship than he himself
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: has attained to, he will be affected with hatred towards the
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: loved object and with envy towards his rival.
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: >>>>>Proof--In proportion as a man thinks, that a loved
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: object is well affected towards him, will be the strength of
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: his self-approval (by the last Prop.), that is (III. xxx. note),
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of his pleasure; he will, therefore (III. xxviii.), endeavour,
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: as far as he can, to imagine the loved object as most closely
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: bound to him:  this endeavour or desire will be increased, if
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: he thinks that someone else has a similar desire (III. xxxi.).
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: But this endeavour or desire is assumed to be checked by
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the image of the loved object in conjunction with the image
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of him whom the loved object has joined to itself; therefore
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (III. xi. note) he will for that reason be affected with pain,
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: accompanied by the idea of the loved object as a cause in
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conjunction with the image of his rival; that is, he will be
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (III. xiii.) affected with hatred towards the loved object
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and also towards his rival (III. xv. Cor.), which latter he
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: will envy as enjoying the beloved object.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: *****Note--This hatred towards an object of love joined
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: with envy is called "Jealousy," which accordingly is nothing
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: else but a wavering of the disposition arising from combined
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: love and hatred, accompanied by the idea of some rival who
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: is envied.  Further, this hatred towards the object of love will
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: be greater, in proportion to the pleasure which the jealous
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: man had been wont to derive from the reciprocated love of
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the said object; and also in proportion to the feelings he had
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: previously entertained towards his rival.  If he had hated him,
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: he will forthwith hate the object of his love, because he
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conceives it is pleasurably affected by one whom he himself
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: hates:  and also because he is compelled to associate the image
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of his loved one with the image of him whom he hates.  This
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: condition generally comes into play in the case of love for a
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: woman:  for he who thinks, that a woman whom he loves
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: prostitutes herself to another, will feel pain, not only because
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: his own desire is restrained, but also because, being compelled
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to associate the image of her he loves with the parts of shame
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and the excreta of another, he therefore shrinks from her.
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: We must add, that a jealous man is not greeted by his beloved
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: with the same joyful countenance as before, and this also gives
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: him pain as a lover, as I will now show.
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: XXXVI. He who remembers a thing, in which he has once taken
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: delight, desires to possess it under the same circumstances as
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: when he first took delight therein.
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: >>>>>Proof--Everything, which a man has seen in conjunction
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: with the object of his love, will be to him accidentally a cause of
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: pleasure (III. xv.); he will, therefore, desire to possess it, in
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conjunction with that wherein he has taken delight; in other words,
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: he will desire to possess the object of his love under the same
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: circumstances as when he first took delight therein.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: <<<<<Corollary--A lover will, therefore, feel pain if one of the
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: aforesaid attendant circumstances be missing.
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: >>>>>Proof--For, in so far as he finds some circumstance to
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: be missing, he conceives something which excludes its existence.
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: As he is assumed to be desirous for love's sake of that thing or
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: circumstance (by the last Prop.), he will, in so far as he conceives
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: it to be missing, feel pain (III. xix.).  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: *****This pain, in so far as it has reference to the absence of
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the object of love, is called "Regret."
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: XXXVII. Desire arising through pain or pleasure, hatred or
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: love, is greater in proportion as the emotion is greater.
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: >>>>>Proof--Pain diminishes or constrains a man's power
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of activity (III. xi. note), in other words (III. vii.), diminishes or
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: constrains the effort, wherewith he endeavours to persist in his
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: own being; therefore (III. v.) it is contrary to the said endeavour:
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: thus all the endeavours of a man affected by pain are directed
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to removing that pain.  But (by the definition of pain), in proportion
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: as the pain is greater, so also is it necessarily opposed to a greater
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: part of man's power of activity; therefore the greater the pain,
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the greater the power of activity employed to remove it; that is,
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the greater will be the desire or appetite in endeavouring to
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: remove it.  Again, since pleasure (III. xi. note) increases or aids
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: a man's power of activity, it may easily be shown in like manner,
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that a man affected by pleasure has no desire further than to
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: preserve it, and his desire will be in proportion to the magnitude
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of the pleasure.
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Lastly, since hatred and love are themselves emotions of pain
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and pleasure, it follows in like manner that the endeavour, appetite,
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: or desire, which arises through hatred or love, will be greater in
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: proportion to the hatred or love.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: XXXVIII. If a man has begun to hate an object of his love, so
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: that love is thoroughly destroyed, he will, causes being equal,
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: regard it with more hatred than if he had never loved it, and
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: his hatred will be in proportion to the strength of his former love.
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: >>>>>Proof--If a man begins to hate that which he had loved,
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: more of his appetites are put under restraint than if he had never
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: loved it.  For love is a pleasure (III. xiii. note) which a man
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: endeavours as far as he can to render permanent (III. xxviii.);
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: he does so by regarding the object of his love as present, and
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: by affecting it as far as he can pleasurably; this endeavour is
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: greater in proportion as the love is greater, and so also is the
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: endeavour to bring about that the beloved should return his
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: affection (III. xxxiii.).  Now these endeavours are constrained
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: by hatred towards the object of love (III. xiii. Cor. and III. xxiii.);
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: wherefore the love (III. xi. note) will for this cause also be
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: affected with pain, the more so in proportion as his love has
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: been greater; that is, in addition to the pain caused by hatred,
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: there is a pain caused by the fact that he has loved the object;
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: wherefore the lover will regard the beloved with greater pain,
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: or in other words, will hate it more than if he had never loved
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: it, and with the more intensity in proportion as his former love
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: was greater.  Q.E.D.
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: XXXIX. He who hates anyone will endeavour to do him an
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: injury, unless he fears that a greater injury will thereby accrue
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to himself; on the other hand, he who loves anyone will, by the
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: same law, seek to benefit him.
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: >>>>>Proof--To hate a man is (III. xiii. note) to conceive him
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: as a cause of pain; therefore he who hates a man will endeavour
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to remove or destroy him.  But if anything more painful, or, in
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: other words, a greater evil, should accrue to the hater thereby
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: --and if the hater thinks he can avoid such evil by not carrying
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: out the injury, which he planned against the object of his hatred
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: --he will desire to abstain from inflicting that injury (III. xxviii.),
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and the strength of his endeavour (III. xxxvii.) will be greater
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: than his former endeavour to do injury, and will therefore prevail
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: over it, as we asserted.  The second part of this proof proceeds
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in the same manner.  Wherefore he who hates another, etc.
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Q.E.D.

text: *****Note--By "good" I here mean every kind of pleasure,
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and all that conduces thereto, especially that which satisfies our
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: longings, whatsoever they may be.  By "evil," I mean every kind
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of pain, especially that which frustrates our longings.  For I have
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: shown (III. ix. note) that we in no case desire a thing because we
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: deem it good, but, contrariwise, we deem a thing good because
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: we desire it:  consequently we deem evil that which we shrink
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: from; everyone, therefore, according to his particular emotions,
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: judges or estimates what is good, what is bad, what is better,
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: what is worse, lastly, what is best, and what is worst.  Thus a
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: miser thinks that abundance of money is the best, and want of
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: money the worst; an ambitious man desires nothing so much as
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: glory, and fears nothing so much as shame.  To an envious man
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: nothing is more delightful than another's misfortune, and nothing
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: more painful than another's success.  So every man, according
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to his emotions, judges a thing to be good or bad, useful or
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: useless.  The emotion, which induces a man to turn from that
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which he wishes, or to wish for that which he turns from, is
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: called "timidity," which may accordingly be defined as "the fear
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: whereby a man is induced to avoid an evil which he regards as
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: future by encountering a lesser evil" (III. xxviii.).  But if the evil
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which he fears be shame, timidity becomes "bashfulness."
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Lastly, if the desire to avoid a future evil be checked by the
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: fear of another evil, so that the man knows not which to choose,
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

title: Ethics — Part 3

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: causes the principal emotions and vacillations of spirit, which

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: DEFINITIONS OF THE EMOTIONS
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: I. "Desire" is the actual essence of man, in so far as it is conceived,
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: as determined to a particular activity by some given modification
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of itself.
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: ^^^^^Explanation--We have said above, in the note to
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Prop. ix. of this part, that desire is appetite, with consciousness
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: thereof; further, that appetite is the essence of man, in so far
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: as it is determined to act in a way tending to promote its own
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: persistence.  But, in the same note, I also remarked that,
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: strictly speaking, I recognize no distinction between appetite
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and desire.  For whether a man be conscious of his appetite
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: or not, it remains one and the same appetite.  Thus, in order
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to avoid the appearance of tautology, I have refrained from
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: explaining desire by appetite; but I have taken care to define
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: it in such a manner, as to comprehend, under one head, all
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: those endeavours of human nature, which we distinguish by
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: the terms appetite, will, desire, or impulse.  I might, indeed,
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: have said, that desire is the essence of man, in so far as it is
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: conceived as determined to a particular activity; but from
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: such a definition (cf. II. xxiii.) it would not follow that the
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mind can be conscious of its desire or appetite.  Therefore,
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: in order to imply the cause of such consciousness, it was
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: necessary to add, "in so far as it is determined by some given
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: modification," &c.  For, by a modification of man's essence,
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: we understand every disposition of the said essence, whether
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: such disposition be innate, or whether it be conceived solely
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: under the attribute of thought, or solely under the attribute
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: of extension, or whether, lastly, it be referred simultaneously
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to both these attributes.  By the term desire, then, I here
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: mean all man's endeavours, impulses, appetites, and volitions,
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: which vary according to each man's disposition, and are,
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: therefore, not seldom opposed one to another, according
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: as a man is drawn in different directions, and knows not
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: where to turn.
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: II. "Pleasure" is the transition of a man from a less to a greater
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: perfection.
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: III. "Pain" is the transition of a man from a greater to a less
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: perfection.
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: ^^^^^Explanation--I say transition:  for pleasure is not
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: perfection itself.  For, if man were born with the perfection
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to which he passes, he would possess the same, without the
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: emotion of pleasure.  This appears more clearly from the
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: consideration of the contrary emotion, pain.  No one can
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: deny, that pain consists in the transition to a less perfection,
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and not in the less perfection itself:  for a man cannot be
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: pained, in so far as he partakes of perfection of any degree.
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: Neither can we say, that pain consists in the absence of a
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: greater perfection.  For absence is nothing, whereas the
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: emotion of pain is an activity; wherefore this activity can
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: only be the activity of transition from a greater to a less
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: perfection--in other words, it is an activity whereby a man's
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: power of action is lessened or constrained (cf. III. xi. note).
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: I pass over the definitions of merriment, stimulation, melancholy,
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: and grief, because these terms are generally used in reference
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: to the body, and are merely kinds of pleasure or pain.

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: (cf. III. lii. and note).

author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: reason, why the mind, from the contemplation of one thing,
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: straightway falls to the contemplation of another thing, namely,
title: Ethics — Part 3
author: Spinoza, Benedictus de

text: because the images of the two things are so associated and
title: Ethics — Part 3
